newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bonn tax group plans tightening on share, property.
newsitem.headline: Bonn tax group plans tightening on share, property.

text.p: Germany's new tax code would tighten rules on short-term gains from share and property sales while cutting company taxes for non-distributed profit and earnings, Bonn's tax work group said on Thursday.
Beginning in 1998, investors would be allowed to sell shares tax-free after holding them one year instead of six months, and property after 10 years instead of two, a commission member told Reuters.
The commission, which unveils its reform proposal Thursday evening, would also cut company tax to 28 percent for distributed earnings and to 40 percent for non-distributed profits, the member said.
The new corporate tax rules would also go into effect in 1998, while the tax on life insurance profits would become effective immediately, the commission member said.
The proposals are part of a broad overhaul of Germany's heavy-handed tax code that has strained Chancellor Helmut Kohl's centre-right coalition.

After months of haggling between Kohl's Christian Democrats (CDU) and junior partner Free Democrats (FDU), the group reached a compromise last night on a package that lowers taxes by a net of 30 billion marks.
Finance Minister Theo Waigel is scheduled to introduce the proposal Thursday evening.
